content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very nice one, maybe if it is possible, add one or two validators with `10` as part of the numbers. One without solution and one with a `0` as a pair.
--
Example:
`10 5 8 -3` 
`9 10 9 64 9 0 12`

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I believe that's a cool puzzle. Close to other submissions (https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/925520f9f06506dcfc0be734d648d3fb5b9c) but not exactly the same so I think it can be approved.

Small note: there is an extra space in the input string of the Validator 2, is that on purpose?
What happens if there is more than 1 couple of element that match the criteria. (e.g. 1 2 9 8 ) ?

Goal sections
* Better to specify "any" two elements.

Input section
* Better to specify "space-separated" integers.

Constraints section
* You may remove the second constraint as it is more of a description than a constraint.

Output requirement
* As per contribution guidelines, binary output should be avoided in a clash of code:
https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/contribution-guidelines
So please change the output requirement so that there are more than two possible answers in total for all cases. For example, instead of requiring true/false as the answer, maybe the requirement is to output the indices of the two numbers which add up to 10 instead.
* If you indeed require indices to be output instead, then I also suggest to add a constraint that either 1 pair or no pair of numbers add up to 10.

Cases
* Each pair of test and validator should be similar but remain different. Please revise the cases.

Thanks.

Thanks for the relevant feedback !

I updated the clash accordingly.
I went with your suggestion of returning the indices :)

Hi ManuS,

Thanks for your feedback !

It is, indeed, a special case.
There is a constraint mentioning the fact that there can only be 1 pair or no pair in the list :)

We could lift this constraint and handle multiple matching pairs. Asking to return the pair with the lowest or highest indices, for instance.
But I have the feeling that will make the clash more complex to understand.

Thanks for the approval Gautzilla.
I wasn't aware of the clash you linked.
It has, indeed, some similarities.  
(I removed the extra space, it was a typo)

Good idea !

I added the tests cases :)
